subject: RE: [junit] Re: black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... The most important thing is that the component obeys the contracts of its interface.  I do use assertions for the internals of the class--something that
messageBody:
> From: ipreussde [mailto:ilja.preuss@...]
>
> > Imagine buying a radio. We all know how a radio works. It's
> interface
> > is the same no matter where you go--you have a control to
> change the
> > station and a control to change the volume. There are several
> models
> > of the radio, and in a store, there are many instances of each
> model.
> >
> >[...]
> >
> > You can only really do black box testing in this type of
> environment.
> > You have the advantage of knowing what the component does. You
> don't
> > know how it does it--and from the perspective of using the
> component
> > you don't care.
>
> Yes. But from the perspective of developing the component, you *do*
> care. I am sure that radios get white box tested at the plant.

The most important thing is that the component obeys the contracts
of its interface. I do use assertions for the internals of the
class--something that JUnit cannot do.

>
> > I have created a test harness using JUnit for my components, so
> that I
> > can test several component types with one TestCase. It's a
> beautiful
> > thing.
> >
> > Now, If I tried to write a white-box test on my component, I run
> into
> > some serious setbacks. That white-box (or micro test) is tied to
> the
> > component implementation. I cannot reuse that test on another
> > implementation of the same component interface. That is a serious
> > drawback to me.
>
> A very serious drawback of not adjusting tests to implementation
> details is that sufficient tests for one implementation are most
> probably insufficient for another. That doesn't mean that you can't
> reuse them - it's just that it isn't safe relying on them.

True. However I do not throw away tests--I add them. As we find more
ways of breaking the component, we add that test to the component's
testcase. That introduces regression testing--and ensures that all
implementations of a component don't break when a new regression is
added.

Two truths:

* You can't know all the design from the beginning.
* You can't know all the tests from the beginning.

It is an iterative process. As things fail, you add a regression test,
then you fix the problem. The order is important--write the test before
you fix the problem.
